page.title: 03Mow Cop
page.content: Between the Staffordshire Moorlands and the Cheshire Plain rises a ridge of Millstone grit which is four miles long,broadening at its southern end into a mountain just over 1,100 feet high.This is Mow Cop.The Cheshire side has the remains of an ancient oak woodland,which falls steeply to about 400 feet.The Staffordshire side falls more gently into the Biddulph Valley. The name is probably a corruption of Moel Cop could come from either old English Coepp or the latin Cappa,which means top or head.There is evidence that the Romans used this area for mining.During the 14th century querms were produced.Later coal became the important industry.Today there is just one mill producing Fustian.The land around is used mainly for rough grazing and is dotted with remains of old quarries.
